definition:
The [*Adams Prize*]{} is a prize awarded by the University of Cambridge
to a young mathematician working in the United Kingdom. Like the Fields
Medal, age 40 is the specific cutoff for this prize.

These prizes were instituted in honor of the British mathematician John
Couch Adams in 1850, soon after he discovered Neptune. Each year the
prize committee chooses a specific field of mathematics and awards the
prize to a mathematician working in that field.
